blocks.title: Overview
blocks.text: Taskmaster is a self-organising innovation backlog prioritised by comparing each Initiative's contributions to overarching Drivers & Enablers.  Each Initiative (basically an innovation project expressed in Lean Startup language) advertises the skills it needs to succeed, and users can sign up to Initiatives as they like.
blocks.imgAlt: Drivers prioritise Enablers, which prioritise Initiatives, which are signed up to by self-organised users.

blocks.title: Why use it?
blocks.text: You want to make it easy for your staff to self-organise around innovation work (Initiatives), without needing a command-and-control hierarchy telling them what to do, but you want that work linked to overarching corporate priorities (Drivers and Enablers) and you want completely accountable visibility of the work that everyone is doing, along with skill utilisation, shortages, vacancy fulfilment rates, costs, and so on.

blocks.title: Getting Started
blocks.text: If you're new, you might want to explore each of the tabs to find out more about what each one does.  You might also want to look at your profile in the top right, and add the skills you're comfortable with, as well as your availability to work on any Initiatives.

If you ask the question 'Why is our organisation doing [something]?', then drivers are the last answer you get before you get to the answer 'because that's why our organisation exists.' They are the very-highest level expression of a need in an organisation, and even large organisations would only expect to have a handful each year. Drivers are the only directly prioritisable type of task in TASKMASTER, prioritised as a simple ordered list.

Enablers are the next level down from Drivers.  Whereas Drivers are a high-level abstraction of what an organisation needs to do, Enablers are a strategy for how to deliver against those Drivers.  They don't explain exactly how this will be done - that's down to intitiatives - but they do give a broad direction of what's important.  Enablers are prioritised by specifying their contribution level to one or more Drivers.

Initiatives are work packages expressed as Lean Startups.  Each specifies dates for when it is currently planned, as well as the skills it needs to test its hypotheses. Like Enablers, Initiatives are prioritised by how much their results contribute to their higher level priorities - in the case of Initiatives, these will be one or more Enablers.
See how each task contributes to other tasks, their priorities, and reprioritise them.
Take a look at which vacancies are running when, and what skills they need, as well as other stats on skills availability and usage.
Filter the current view, for example to find vacancies that match your skills. The filters change depending on the tab you're on, but filter settings are remembered between tabs.
This is your profile.  You can logout here, reset hints (to restore any hints you have previously hidden) and view all the hints available

blocks.title: Adding skills, availability, and a bio.
blocks.text: If you click on EDIT above, you can add a bio, as well as add any skill groups you feel comfortable working within, and dates you may be available to work on initiatives.

blocks.title: The biggest picture
blocks.text: Drivers are the highest level of direction that can be provided by an organisation, and be clearly self-justifying under the scope of your organisation.
A large organisation (e.g. thousands of employees) should only expect a handful of drivers each year.  To take Ford as an example, a driver might be 'Sell more cars to the younger generation.'
Enablers are high-level directions on the ways in which a driver can be fulfilled.  Across a large organisation (i.e. thousands of employees), we should only expect a couple dozen of these.
To take Ford as an example, an enabler to the driver 'Sell more cars which appeal to the younger generation' might be 'Build a Ford racing car and come first in Le Mans'

blocks.title: Prioritising Enablers
blocks.text: Enablers are not directly prioritised by you.  Instead, you specify the driver(s) that the enabler contributes towards and how much it contributes towards it, and the priority of the enabler is calculated based on weightings from those relationships.

blocks.title: Fast and Lean
blocks.text: Intiatives should be short and sweet and designed to prove hypotheses.  That could be proving that a particular service or product is useful by providing a quick prototype to test its usage, that something can be de-risked, or that some change in policy would yield certain results.

Whatever it is, Lean Startup (http://theleanstartup.com/principles) teaches us that we should aim to prove it as simply and as quickly as we can.  That's because many startups have failed before they realise it, due to risks they didn't realise they had that were based on bad assumptions.

blocks.title: Don't use Initiatives to build assetts
blocks.text: This isn't the place to build big products or services, it's the place to prove something about them - a new feature, it's feasibility, etc.  For example, a popular song identification service didn't start by building complex sound analysis software to identify music, because they didn't want to go to all that effort before they knew people would use it.  So instead, they first tested the idea by having people pick up the phone and literally try and guess the song.  That proved the concept before they had to spend too much money.  This is how you should think when writing initiatives.

blocks.title: Prioritising Initiatives
blocks.text: Initiatives are not directly prioritised by you.  Instead, you specify the enabler(s) that the initiative contributes towards and how much it contributes towards it, and the priority of the initiative is calculated based on weightings from those relationships.

blocks.title: Resourcing Initiatives
blocks.text: Once you have written your initiative and saved it, you will be able to add vacancies, and then other users will be able to sign up to them.

blocks.title: The Minimum Viable Team
blocks.text: When adding vacancies to an initiative, think about the minimum team you need to prove the hypotheses.  If those skills aren't defined yet, you can add them as you go (but check they don't exist with another spelling first!)

blocks.title: Don't forget about your users
blocks.text: Skills can be a specialist type of developer, or other expertise, as well as a member of a specific team, but it's important to add facilitation (like people who have Lean Startup Initiatives) before) and stakeholders (like the people who will use the product, so they can be part of the design from the start.)
